title: Convict jailed for 28 years over murder of 9-yr-old
author: BY Kumudu Upul Shantha
Content: Panadura High Court Judge Saman Kumara yesterday (13) sentenced an accused to 28 years Rigorous Imprisonment (RI) who pleaded guilty to murdering a nine-year-old girl in Atulugama, Panadura. The Court also instructed the convict to pay a sum of three million rupees as compensation to the mother of the victim, Fathima Ayesha of Atulugama and warned that failure to pay the compensation would result in a further six and a half years of imprisonment. The Court sentenced the convict, having considered the indictments filed against him by the Attorney General. The convict was identified as Farook Ganeshanathan who had been a friend of the victim’s father. Deputy Solicitor General Janaka Bandara along with Senior State Counsel Lakshman Perera, who prosecuted, stated that the actions resorted to by the accused had further underscored the viciousness of the present day society. They therefore urged the Court to impose the severest possible penalties and fines on the accused so as to deter others from committing similar offences. The lawyers said that they hoped the High Court would not let off the accused lightly as he is a known to be hardcore criminal. Taking the submissions of the DSG and the Senior State Counsel into perusal, Judge Kumara slapped the aforementioned punishments and fines on the convict. The Bandaragama Police and the Panadura Division Special Crimes Unit, probing the incident, had uncovered that the convict had coaxed the victim to go with him to a nearby shrub jungle with the intention of raping her after she had gone to a boutique, situated close to her house, on 27 May two years ago. The Police had uncovered that though the convict had attempted to rape the deceased he had been prevented from doing so due to loud screaming on the part of the victim and afterwards the convict had submerged the victim in a nearby muddy paddy field causing her death. During the probe the Police had also gathered information that the convict, who had been a close friend of her father, had been known to her family having visited them often and therefore she had willingly gone with him on the ill-fated day. After the Police had identified the accused, the Attorney General had filed indictments against him, before the High Court, in a short span of time.

title: Farmers protest against Amaraweera
author: BY Savani Sheashadhi and Chamodya Senarathna
Content: During a meeting convened to discuss preparations for the forthcoming Yala Season, officials from the Ministry of Agriculture and those of farmers’ organisations vehemently protested against the subject Minister.  Among those attending the meeting were Minister Mahinda Amaraweera, Minister of Irrigation, Wildlife and Forest Conservation Pavithra Wanniarachchi and State Ministers Sasheendra Rajapaksa and Mohan Priyadarshana Silva. Initially, officials from the agriculture, irrigation and Mahaweli sectors, aired their views on planning for the upcoming season. Subsequently, the emcee of the event invited Minister Amaraweera to speak. However, just as he was about to commence his speech, representatives from farmer unions stood up and protested against the Minister. They expressed their frustration, stating that they had not travelled from far-flung areas to listen to the Minister’s views. The farmers’ union representatives demanded to be allowed to air their grievances before the Minister’s speech. Minister Amaraweera consented to stay back and listen to the farmers’ grievances, explaining that he had intended to speak first to break the ice. The farmer union representatives questioned why a national agriculture policy was not in place, expressing concerns that farmers were being controlled by businessmen due to this shortfall.  Minister Amaraweera explained that during his tenure as the subject Minister, six years ago, he had initiated a national agriculture policy, which was examined by a committee led by Prof. Gamini Seneviratne. He noted that the policy proposal suggested incorporating sectors such as fisheries, irrigation and livestock, which would take some time to compile. The farmer representatives insisted that the views of farmers should be included in the final draft of the policy. Minister Amaraweera suggested that the farmers’ suggestions could be submitted to Parliament as future amendments. The farmer union representatives alleged that they were not receiving reasonable prices for their harvests during the ongoing Maha Season. They also complained about the skyrocketing prices of agricultural equipment and pesticides, demanding government intervention and relief. They questioned how officials and traders could decide the price of their harvest after they had worked hard in the fields. Additionally, they requested the presence of officials responsible for deciding the prices of paddy at the meeting. Furthermore, they highlighted damages caused to their crops by wild animals and sought both short and long-term relief measures. Minister Wanniarachchi expressed her disapproval of the farmer union representatives making baseless allegations against Minister Amaraweera, emphasising his efforts to revive the agrarian industry, even within the Cabinet. She noted that Minister Amaraweera had worked diligently to obtain the maximum price for paddy on numerous occasions.

title: Cabinet green light to amend OSA
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet has approved a resolution, forwarded by Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles, to make several amendments to the recently enacted Online Safety Act (OSA), according to Cabinet Spokesman Minister Bandula Gunawardena.  Speaking at yesterday’s (13) Cabinet media briefing, Minister Gunawardena said input from industry experts, regarding the Online Safety Act, had been received and considered. The amendments to the Online Safety Act, Minister Gunawardena explained, will be drafted based on these proposals.  The Government emphasised that while the provisions of the Online Safety Act are currently being implemented, following its passage in Parliament, amendments proposed during committee sessions could only be aligned with decisions made by the Supreme Court.  Consequently, there was no opportunity to incorporate the amendments proposed by industry experts. To address this, the Cabinet approved the proposal to engage with experts in the field further and incorporate their proposed amendments into the draft bill for the Online Safety Act.

title: Manoj Gamage resigns from NMRA Director Board
author: By Dilanthi Jayamanne
Content: Lawyer Manoj Gamage, who was on the Board of Directors of the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA), handed in his letter of resignation to Health Minister, Dr. Ramesh Pathirana yesterday (13).     Two more members of the NMRA Board also stepped down from their respective positions. All of them were appointed to the board by former Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella.  In his letter of resignation addressed to the Minister of Health, Gamage noted that his intention to step down from his position in the NMRA was effective 13 February.  In his letter, Gamage stressed that he had endeavoured to work for the betterment of the Authority in his capacity as a lawyer. While serving as a Director, he said he had done his maximum to make appropriate decisions to overcome some of the failures in the Authority. They included completing and submitting annual reports which had not been provided from 2016 to 2022. Completing all work related to the Corporate Plan of the NMRA and establishing audit committees and conducting audit committee meetings as the former administrations of NMRA had failed to do so.   The former NMRA Director said he had also been instrumental in the recruitment and induction of pharmacists which had not been done for the past eight years.  Gamage’s loyalties and ethics were questioned in December last year when he spoke in defence of former Health Minister Rambukwella, who was accused of being involved in the procurement of a large quantity of low-quality medicinal drugs including the Human Immunoglobulin IV scandal.

title: Health unions’ strike cripples health care services
author: By Dilanthi Jayamanne
Content: More than 80,000 State health service employees warned they would continue their strike today (14) too, despite the severe inconvenience caused to patients seeking treatment from the State health services.  Hospital services were disrupted when 72 trade unions, comprising professions supplementary to medicine, paramedics, a section of nurses and health assistants, including ambulance drivers and cooks, struck work demanding a similar economic justice from the Government.  Several hospitals underwent difficulties in conducting lab tests, scans and dispensing drugs. Routine surgeries and clinical services were also disrupted as a result of the strike. State service hospital administrations had requested for assistance from the Armed forces. Thereby they were deployed to run daily activities of the hospitals affected by the strike. Security Forces maintained the services of Health Assistants in the National Hospitals Colombo and Kandy, National Eye Hospital, Colombo, Teaching Hospitals  Kalubowila, Karapitiya, Mahamodara, Peradeniya, Anuradhapura and Kurunegala and the services at,  Matale, Polonnaruwa, Medirigiriya, Higurakgoda, Batticaloa, Dehiattakandiya , Hambantota, Debarawewa, Ratnapura, Balangoda, Aheliyagoda, Nawalapitiya, Badulla, Elpitiya, Homagama and Kegalle. About 900 troops of the Sri Lanka Army were put on duty at hospitals. Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA warned the trade union leaders, who are up in arms, to refrain from verbally attacking medical practitioners and as a result creating disharmony between health service employees. “We would have to resort to trade union action if these warring trade union leaders do not stop their spiteful verbal attacks targeting doctors.” He said his outfit would decide on a course of action when the Central Committee of the GMOA meets during the course of the week.   “It is not legally or constitutionally possible to give a Disturbance, Availability and Transport (DAT) increase of Rs 35,000 to non-medical health service employees as the particular allowance is exclusively for the medical fraternity. Instead these trade unions should agitate and demand for allowances relevant to their profession,” he said.  Convenor of the Health Service Trade Union Alliance  (HSTUA) Chanaka Dharmawickrema said that although only one of the three nurses’ unions, namely the Government Nursing Officers’ Association (GNOA) had  joined the strike nearly 20,000 nurses (50% of the total number)  had supported the cause.  The All Ceylon Nurses Union (ACNU) is scheduled to stage a protest today (14) demanding for much needed economic justice by increasing allowances and paying them the ‘Sleepless, Transport and Risk’ Allowance (STR) and awarding the proper title for Nursing Sisters who had completed a Post Graduate Course.

title: Electronic Media Broadcasting Authority Act soon
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Mass Media Shantha Bandara said the Electronic Media Broadcasting Authority Bill is expected to be tabled in Parliament and enacted soon. Additionally, he noted that a national media policy has been drafted and is presently being considered by the Cabinet for approval. State Minister Bandara was speaking at a news conference held at the President’s Media Centre yesterday (13). The State Minister also said: “In tackling today’s prominent challenge of financial management, we directed our attention towards addressing revenue and expenditure issues. Specifically, we concentrated on the 16 institutions falling under the Ministry, a significant portion of which relied on Treasury allocations. As a result, initiatives were undertaken to enhance the self-sufficiency of these entities, enabling them to operate independently. Particularly, in our efforts to enhance Sri Lanka Rupavahini Corporation and the Sri Lanka Broadcasting Corporation, we engaged in discussions with their management, leading to crucial decisions that have garnered positive responses. Further, Independent Television Network and the Associated Newspapers of Ceylon Limited (Lakehouse) have undergone significant transformations. We anticipate turning these institutions into profitable entities by next year.” Moreover, the Postal Department’s revenue projection saw a notable increase from Rs 9,268 million in 2022 to Rs 13,616 million in 2023. Through improved services and enhanced management practices without imposing additional burdens on the public, we managed to reduce the department’s losses from Rs 7,173 million in 2021 to Rs 6,832 million in 2022, and further down to Rs 3,222 million in 2023. We are confident that by 31 December 2024, the Postal Department will operate as a self-sustaining, profit-making institution independent of Treasury funds. Additionally, Cabinet has approved a special project programme worth Rs 10 billion, establishing a joint venture between the private and public sectors. This initiative aims to expedite international goods exchange processes. Further, plans are underway to launch a courier service for goods exchange in the Western Province this year, utilising 200 three-wheelers and 50 motorcycles, the State Minister added.  (SRM)

title: Presidential Election as scheduled, General Election next year
author: BY Methmalie Dissanayake
Content: With political arena in the country heating up due to the election pressure, the President’s Media Division (PMD) yesterday (13) announced that the Presidential Election will be held first and the General Election will follow.  Issuing a statement, the PMD said the Presidential Election will be conducted within the stipulated timeframe and according to the existing scheduleand the general election would be held next year.  Furthermore, the PMD clarified that financial allocations for the General Election will be incorporated in the 2025 budget. Responsibility for overseeing the electoral process lies with the Election Commission, and the government will maintain communication with the Commission as and when necessary, the PMD added.  However, the PDM did not divulge any information about holding the indefinitely postponed local government elections and Provincial Council elections.  The PMD’s statement came amidst the allegations by several parties, including the main Opposition Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) and Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) that there is an attempt to postpone the Presidential Election by bringing proposals to abolish the Executive Presidency.  The tenure of the President, elected in November 2019, ends in November 2024. As per the Constitution of Sri Lanka, the term of five years for an elected President does not change even if a President steps down during the period and another person takes over. Therefore, the election must be held one month before the conclusion of the incumbent President’s term. The Election Commission of Sri Lanka is responsible for holding the Presidential Election during the stipulated period as per the law.

title: SC defers verdict indefinitely
author: By Sandasen Marasinghe
Content: The Supreme Court concluded the hearing of an appeal challenging State Minister Diana Gamage’s Parliamentary membership.    The Supreme Court Bench comprising Justice Gamini Amarasekara, Justice Kumuduni Wickremasinghe and Justice Janak de Silva decided to defer the verdict indefinitely. Shavindra Fernando, PC represented State Minister Gamage.  Social activist Oshala Herath filed the appeal in the Supreme Court two weeks after the petition, filed challenging Gamage’s Parliamentary membership, was dismissed by the Court of Appeal in a majority verdict.  The petitioner sought from the Court of Appeal a Writ of Quo Warranto declaring that Diana Gamage is unqualified to be an MP in light of her dual citizenship. Counsel Hafeel Farisz represented the petitioner. Farman Cassim, PC represented the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) General Secretary.

title: CEB willing to pay interest for security deposits
author: By Sandasen Marasinghe
Content: The Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) informed the Supreme Court that interest would be paid for security deposits collected from consumers in 2023.   Deputy Solicitor General Nirmalan Vigneswaran informed the Court by way of a motion that the CEB had decided to pay an annual interest of 11.67 per cent for security deposits collected from consumers in 2023.  The motion also informed the Supreme Court Bench comprising Justice S. Thurairaja, Justice Gamini Amarasekera and Justice Kumuduni Wickremasinghe, that the CEB has decided to pay the interest beginning January 2024.  The motion was submitted in regard to the Fundamental Rights petition filed by the Electricity Consumers’ Association stating that the CEB was violating the fundamental rights of all CEB consumers by not paying interest on the deposits that they make when applying for new connections. The petitioner argued per the provisions of the CEB Act, consumers are entitled to interest for deposits made to the CEB.  The petitioner prayed the Supreme Court to declare that the CEB consumers’ fundamental rights have been violated by the actions of the CEB and also to order the CEB to pay interest to electricity consumers. The CEB, the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka and the Ministry of Power and Energy were named as respondents.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Innovative Grama Niladhari Chandika receives recognition
author: BY Farhan Nizamdeen – Galle
Content: M.W. Chandika Dinesh had functioned as the Grama Niladhari of the 41/E, Beligaswella Grama Seva Division coming under the purview of the Galle, Karandeniya Divisional Secretariat. He was also selected as the best Grama Seva Officer of the Galle District Promotion Awards Festival 2023. Speaking on his achievement he stated “I assumed my post in this Division on 1 January, 2023. The Karandeniya Divisional Secretariat is mostly made up of low-income groups. At the time I came here this place had gone to rack and ruin. However, since taking over duties I managed to set up an office within  two-months. I even held a lantern competition to mark last year’s Poson Festival. The biggest achievement is I was able to establish a small food bank within my office premises. This food bank consists of essential items for the public and if certain families are in need of such items, it could cater to their needs via this food bank.  Not only that, I have also created a medicinal and vegetable bank as well to look into the needs of these low-income families. Besides all this I have also been operating a children’s society and a relief society to cater to these people in this Secretariat”. Dinesh added that he has initiated each of his concepts with the unwavering support received from Karandeniya Divisional Secretary Ruwin Maduthanthri and Galle District Secretary Shantha Weerasiinghe.

title: Chandima says Kamal and Army Chief apologised to him
author: By Buwanaka S. Perera
Content: As per the directive of the Privilege Committee of Parliament, Defence Ministry Secretary General Kamal Gunaratne and Army Commander Lt. General Vikum Liyanage apologised to him over the ‘threaterning remarks’ hurled against him last year during a parliamentary committee meeting, MP Chandima Weerakkody said on Monday (12). He revealed this to Ceylon Today on Monday (12).  The alleged incident occurred during a Sectoral Oversight Committee meeting on National Security held on 5 October 2023. MP Weerakkody said he raised concerns about the need to reduce expenses of high-ranking military officials instead of laying off soldiers to cut costs. Weerakkody said he questioned an allocation of Rs 80 million for constructing the garden of the Army Commander’s official residence and the presence of soldiers, dogs, vehicles and many others accompanying the Defense Secretary during his jogging sessions at Independence Square, said and added that in response, the Defence Ministry Secretary and Army Commander threatened him, implying they could physically harm him if necessary. After an investigation by the Privilege Committee, Defence Ministry Secretary Kamal Gunaratne, Army Commander Lt. Gen. Vikum Liyanage and Sectoral Oversight Committee on National Security Chairman MP Sarath Weerasekara were summoned before the Committee on Privileges. Speaking further, Weerakkody emphasised that while MPs, public officials, and military personnel are entitled to certain privileges, they should not abuse them for personal gain. He criticised the Defence Ministry Secretary for not following proper security procedures and stated that he accepts the apology.

title: Aswesuma appeals in the North completed
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe informed that the investigations related to the appeals of the Aswesuma Welfare Scheme have been completed in the Northern Province.  The discussion for carrying out the second phase of the Aswesuma Welfare Project was held yesterday (13) at the new auditorium of the Ministry of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies in Colombo. Governor of the Northern Province P.S.M. Charles also participated in this discussion. The Aswesuma Welfare Project has been promoted islandwide and it is planned to start the second phase of this project on 15 February. The discussion was held to get the cooperation of the provincial councils for this project which is being carried out with the cooperation of divisional secretariats and district secretariats, she said. During the first phase of the Aswesuma welfare scheme, 1.1 million appeals were received islandwide. Semasinghe mentioned that the Northern Province was the first to complete the appeal hearings and complete the beneficiaries’ data. Governor Charles said the data of low-income families in the Northern Province is ready and it will be easier to select new beneficiaries through this. In addition, steps have been taken to carry out sustainable development projects for low-income families, according to Charles.

title: International Bhagavad Gita Festival 2024 to be held at Nelum Pokuna
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved the International Bhagavad Gita Festival 2024 or ‘International Gita Mahotsav’ to be held in Sri Lanka.  The International Gita Mahotsav is conducted by the Kurukshetra Development Board (KDB) in Haryana State in India to pay tribute to the sacred ‘Bhagavad Gita’ along with the series of religious activities related to sacred Bhagavad Gita, which is considered to be the most sacred book of Hindu devotees.  During recent years it has been held overseas and this year around the International Holy Bhagavad Gita festival for 2024 was proposed to be held in Sri Lanka.  Accordingly, Cabinet approved the proposal  by the Minister of Buddha Sasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs, Vidura Wickremanayake to      conduct the festival at the Nelum Pokuna Theatre premises from 1 to 3 March 2024 with the financial sponsorship of the Kurukshetra Development Board in Haryana.

title: National Hospital, Children’s Hospital for Biyagama
author: Author not found
Content: The Government is planning to address the increasing demand for health services in Biyagama which comes under the purview of the Gampaha District by establishing a National Hospital and a Children’s Hospital.  With the region serving as a key service delivery hub due to population growth and industrialisation, the necessity for expanded healthcare facilities has been acknowledged. Following the approval of a proposal by President Ranil Wickremesinghe and Health Minister Dr. Ramesh Pathirana, the Cabinet has given the green light for the project. It involves acquiring two plots of land spanning seven acres and three roods in the Biyagama North Grama Niladhari Division, along with the provision of necessary infrastructure. The initiative is set to be implemented through a public-private partnership model, aiming to effectively meet the rising healthcare demands of the area.

title: UAE hosts meeting on future labour relations
author: Author not found
Content: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) is hosting a major meeting of Asian nations, including Sri Lanka, to discuss the future of labour relations and government initiatives to boost international job markets. Ministers of Labour and Human Resources from 16 Asian countries, sending and receiving workers, discussed leveraging advanced technology for innovative initiatives aimed at resolving labour disputes and expediting verdicts. They also aimed to strengthen wage protection systems and facilitate skill mobility among participating countries, foreign media reported. The focus was on improving labour market regulations and initiatives. This came during the seventh Abu Dhabi Dialogue (ADD) Ministerial Consultation meeting, held in Dubai on Sunday, 11 February, as part of the World Governments Summit 2024. A total of 16 countries participated in the current edition of the Abu Dhabi Dialogue, including nine workers-sending countries: Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Nepal, Pakistan, Philippines, Sri Lanka, Thailand and Vietnam. Seven workers-receiving countries were also involved and these countries are UAE, Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and Malaysia. Dr. Abdulrahman Al Awar, UAE’s Minister of Human Resources and Emiratisation, affirmed the significance of the Abu Dhabi Dialogue, highlighting its role as a pivotal forum and consultative platform focusing on labour mobility in the region. He emphasised its importance as a crucial foresight platform throughout its successive sessions, aimed at monitoring anticipated future challenges in the labour markets across the Asia-Pacific region. He said: “Abu Dhabi Dialogue contributed significantly to the integration of procedures and decisions, as well as the adoption of sustainable solutions for key challenges, offering a platform to showcase innovative ideas, leading global trends, and successful regional initiatives. “Labour markets are undergoing major economic and social transformations, along with wide-ranging structural changes that impact the nature of work and the type of businesses, jobs, and skills required to keep pace with global transformations, especially the radical changes affecting the core aspects of economic development. “This has created a unique set of challenges, imposing new trends in labour market policies that align with the nature of these pivotal transformations.” Minister Al Awar said the Abu Dhabi Dialogue Ministerial Consultation presents an ideal opportunity to strengthen partnerships and outline future trends and priorities for collaboration among member States to meet development requirements and make integrated, actionable decisions based on scientific research. Al Awar’s speech also addressed the social protection system for workers in the UAE, which includes the Unemployment Insurance Scheme, the voluntary alternative end-of-service benefits scheme (the Savings Scheme), Wage Protection System, Workers Protection Programme, and other initiatives that serve to enhance and protect the contractual relationship between worker and employer. Manusha Nanayakkara, Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment of Sri Lanka, and former Chair of Abu Dhabi Dialogue, underlined the importance of cooperation, exchanging best practices between member States, and the use of technology to support the governance of labour mobility. Nanayakkara presented the initiatives recently launched by Sri Lanka to support the governance of labour mobility and allow for accurate documentation and certification of skills, to create greater opportunities for workers and raise their efficiency. During the meeting, five countries presented innovative government initiatives. The UAE showcased its social protection system for workers, including the Unemployment Insurance Scheme, which has around seven million subscribers, as well as the voluntary alternative end-of-service benefits scheme, known as the Savings Scheme. The UAE also presented the Labour Market Observatory platform, which provides periodic data in Arabic and English on various labour market indicators, as well as the outcomes of regulatory policies, programmes, and initiatives. The UAE also shed light on the process for submitting and resolving individual labour complaints, along with the Emirates Labour Market Award and its role in enhancing labour market competitiveness and motivating stakeholders to adhere to the highest professional quality and work environment standards. Sri Lanka presented an initiative for a national policy and action plan regarding migration, leveraging the workforce as an economic driver in the country and supporting development through a comprehensive vision to ensure professionalism in recruitment.  The initiative also includes launching a mandatory capacity-building and training programme, listing expatriate workers on insurance and pension lists, along with other incentives, such as housing loan facilities, education support for their children, and an integrated financial system to encourage them to transfer money in foreign currency to their home country.  (Arabian Business)

title: Police Sergeant posthumously promoted SI, Rs 1M compensation
author: Author not found
Content: Acting IGP Deshabandu Thennakoon yesterday (13) paid a visit to the residence of a Police Sergeant who tragically lost his life while attempting to apprehend a suspect in Malwathu Hiripitiya.  The bereaved family of the late officer was offered compensation of Rs 1 million by the Sri Lanka Police. In recognition of his sacrifice, the Police Sergeant was posthumously promoted to the rank of Sub-Inspector (SI) on Monday (12) under the directive of the Acting IGP. The incident occurred during a scuffle as officers from the Malwathu Hiripitiya Police Station sought to detain a suspect in Batepola early Saturday (10). In the ensuing struggle, the suspect attempted to seize the officer’s service firearm, resulting in it being discharged and injuring the officer. The suspect fled with the weapon. The injured Police Sergeant, a 51-year-old resident of Ihala Lunugama, was initially treated at Gampola Hospital before being transferred to the National Hospital Colombo, where he succumbed to injuries on Monday. Subsequently, acting on intelligence, the Police STF apprehended the suspect while he was in hiding at a residence in Bingiriya. The revolver belonging to the Police Sergeant, along with three 9mm bullets and the suspect’s three-wheeler were seized as evidence. Additionally, a woman who assisted the suspect in evading capture was also arrested. The suspect is identified as a 42-year-old resident of Wathuragama, while the female suspect is a 35-year-old resident of Udubaddawa.

title: Using solar panels, LED bulbs only viable solution
author: Author not found
Content: The Sectoral Oversight Committee on Energy and Transport discussed that when a new house is being built, one must also consider how to install solar panels if necessary.  This was discussed when the Sectoral Oversight Committee on Energy and Transport met in Parliament recently under the Chairmanship of MP Nalaka Bandara Kottegoda. Officials representing the Sri Lanka Sustainable Energy Authority were present in the Committee and they explained the progress and future plans of the authority. The Committee focused on deciding a spot to install solar panels in a new house. Officials pointed out that awareness programmes have commenced at provincial level and in the western and north-western provinces.  They further pointed out that although people were concerned about various directions based on various occult sciences, they were not concerned about the direction of the sun when building a house. They also said this situation raised concerns in the installation of solar panels. The committee pointed out the need to inform the public about this situation and encourage the people to install solar panels. Further, attention was paid to encourage the use of LED light bulbs to reduce electricity consumption. The officials pointed out that with the intervention of Sri Lanka Sustainable Energy Authority, it was possible to reduce the price of LED bulbs and popularise them among the people. It was pointed out that by considering the reduction in electricity bills by the use of LED bulbs, the amount spent even by giving LED bulbs for free could be earned in two months. The Committee was of the view that attention must be paid in this regard. In addition, the Annual Report of the Sri Lanka Sustainable Energy Authority for 2020 was also approved. MPs Udayakantha Gunathilaka, Gunathilaka Rajapaksha and Kumarasiri Rathnayaka were present at the meeting.

title: UPI transactions through LankaQR launched
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, accompanied by Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and Prime Minister Pravind Jugnauth of Mauritius, collectively inaugurated the launch of Unified Payment Interface (UPI) services in Sri Lanka and Mauritius, along with RuPay card services in Mauritius, through virtual platform on 12 February. This initiative is aimed at providing benefits to Sri Lankan traders and facilitating Indian tourists visiting Sri Lanka and Mauritius. According to the Sri Lankan Government, as part of the initiative, 20 local banks and financial institutions in Sri Lanka have pledged their support, with plans underway to expand coverage to hot-spot tourism areas with the State Bank of India’s involvement from the Indian side.  The UPI services, is developed by the National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI), and serves as an instant real-time payment system intended to streamline inter-bank transactions through mobile phones. According to the Government of India, this service will be operating with the guidance of the Reserve Bank of India and the Central Bank of Sri Lanka, NPCI International Payments Limited of India and Lanka Pay of Sri Lanka have collaborated for enabling the acceptance of UPI services through LankaQR and that would allow merchants in Sri Lanka to accept seamless digital payments from Indian tourists. Such interlinkage will generate ease among Indian tourists benefiting Sri Lanka’s tourism industry, as well as fostering greater connectivity in the FinTech and digital domain.  President’s Media Division (PMD) in Colombo said with digital payments witnessing a surge in adoption within Sri Lanka, the introduction of UPI transactions via LankaQR comes at a pivotal moment and that the LankaQR, already a preferred method for domestic transactions, offers a fast, secure, and convenient way for users to make payments with a simple scan of a QR code. With approximately 350,000 merchants already equipped to accept QR-based transactions, Sri Lanka is well-prepared to extend this facility to Indian tourists. While launching it, Modi yesterday (12) underlined that digital public infrastructure has brought about a revolutionary change in India, where the smallest of vendors in the remotest of villages are transacting UPI and making digital payments at the inaugural of UPI  services in Sri Lanka and Mauritius. High Commission of India in Colombo, also organised a live screening of the launch event, which was attended in large numbers by representatives of banks, business and Indian community in Colombo. Speaking about the convenience and speed of UPI transactions, Modi informed that more than 100 billion transactions took place through UPI last year worth eight trillion Sri Lankan rupees or one trillion Mauritius rupees. Modi also mentioned making last-mile delivery through the JAM Trinity of bank accounts, Aadhar and mobile phones wherein 400 billion US dollars has been transferred into the bank accounts of beneficiaries. He informed that with CoWin Platform India conducted the world’s biggest vaccination programme. “Use of technology is promoting transparency, reducing corruption and increasing inclusivity in society,” the Prime Minister said.  Further, Modi stressed India’s ‘Neighbourhood First’ policy highlighting that their maritime vision Security and Growth for All in the Region and India’s commitment to regional development and cooperation, emphasising the interconnectedness with its neighbouring countries. President Wickremesinghe reiterated the centuries-old economic relations between India and Sri Lanka and stressed that he hoped to maintain the momentum of connectivity and deepening of the relationship between the two countries.  Addressing the occasion, the Prime Minister of Manutius said it marks a special day for three friendly nations – India, Sri Lanka and Mauritius – when their historic connections take the form of modern digital connect. He said that it is proof of the government’s commitment towards the development of the people. The Prime Minister underlined FinTech connectivity will further strengthen cross-border transactions and connections. “India’s UPI or United Payments Interface comes in a new role today – Uniting Partners with India,” he stressed.   Referring to the Vision Document that was adopted during the last visit of the Sri Lankan President, Modi highlighted the strengthening financial connectivity as its key component. The Prime Minister expressed the confidence that connection with UPI will benefit Sri Lanka and Mauritius and digital transformation will get a boost, local economies will witness positive change and tourism will be promoted. “I am confident that Indian tourists will give priority to destinations with UPI. People of Indian origin living in Sri Lanka and Mauritius and students studying there will also get special benefits from it,” the Prime Minister added. He also said the launch symbolises the success of Global South cooperation. “Our relations are not just about transactions, it is a historical relation,” PM Modi emphasised highlighting the strength of people-to-people relations between the three nations.  Drawing attention to India supporting its neighbouring friends in the last ten years, the Prime Minister said that India stands with its friends in every hour of crisis, be it natural disasters, health-related issues, economic or support on the international stage. “India has been the first responder and will continue to be so,” Modi said highlighting the special attention towards the concerns of the Global South even during India’s G20 presidency.

title: State health sector in continuous strike as talks fail
author: By Dilanthi Jayamanne
Content: The health services trade unions will launch a continuous strike from 6.30 a.m. today (13), as the discussions held with the Ministry of Finance, over the demand for a Disturbance, Availability & Transport (DAT) allowance provided to doctors be granted to them as well failed.  However, considering the inconvenience caused to patients’ services at the children’s hospitals in Colombo and Peradeniya as well as Apeksha Hospital for cancer, all maternity hospitals would be exempted from the strike. Also, all renal hospitals, the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) and central blood bank would not join the strike.  Emergency and essential services related life-saving matters would be conducted. However, no services would be maintained in health institutions where hospital administrations aim to disrupt the strike and maliciously underestimate the effect of this strike. The Health Trade Union Alliance (HTUA), comprising 72 State health service trade unions, warned that they would resort to a continuous strike for economic justice, after talks with the Ministry of Finance failing.  HTUA Convenor, Chanaka Dharmawickrema yesterday (12) said that the leaders of the 72 trade unions of the HTUA, had met and decided to launch a continuous strike from 6.30 a.m. today (13).  HTUA Convenor, Ravi Kumudesh lamented that the committee which had been appointed to bring economic justice to the non-medical services of the State health service had failed in its discussions. In a letter to Health Secretary, Dr. Palitha Mahipala, Kumudesh said talks at the stakeholders’ Committee meeting, appointed on President’s intervention, to discuss possibilities of providing economic justice to the State health service had failed. Representatives from health service unions had met the Finance Ministry officials yesterday (12) but had been unable to arrive at a feasible solution.  He warmed that it resulted in the Executive Council of the HTUA comprising 72 trade unions to unanimously decide on further strike actions.  He called for urgent intervention of the President to resolve the problem by bringing equality and justice to the State health service.

title: NPP trying to become main opposition – Marikkar
author: BY Methmalie Dissanayake
Content: The National People’s Power (NPP) is endeavouring to establish itself as the primary opposition force in the country, Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) Spokesman and MP S. M. Marikkar said yesterday (12).  Marikkar stated, during a news briefing, “From the recent visit of NPP Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake to India, it appears that his party is striving to assume the role of the main opposition in the nation.” He further remarked, “We have no objection to NPP’s aspirations to become the main opposition, as we will be governing when they assume that position.” Additionally, Marikkar expressed optimism about Dissanayake’s visit to India, describing it as a constructive step. He commented, “We view Dissanayake’s trip to India positively. He likely returned with insights into investments and foreign relations.” “As a result of the JVP’s actions thousands of young lives were lost. In the past they criticised the Indian expansion in the country. They killed people and chased away investers, back then. So, we are glad that at least now, the JVP is trytng to turn a new page,” he stressed.

title: Rs 1.5M spent on transport for ‘Urumaya’ launch – Chandima
author: By Buwanaka S. Perera
Content: The Government had spent Rs. 1.5 million for 15 buses to transport 700 people to Dambulla, from the Galle District, to participate in the inauguration of the ‘Urumaya’ land ownership programme and another Rs1,500 had been allocated to provide food for each person attending the event, alleged Galle District MP Chandima Weerakkody. Speaking to Ceylon Today on Monday (12), Weerakkody claimed that the common practice would be for the beneficiaries to collect their land ownership documents from their respective divisional secretariats, and the government should have been more scrupulous in its spending on such an event when the country is still going through an economic crisis.  MP Weerakkody claimed that many of the people who were transported to Dambulla were daily income earners and as a result of the event many lost their income that day.  The parliamentarian further suggested that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) would also agree with him over the point of cutting down such unnecessary expenditures instead of increasing taxes and tariffs on utilities and burdening the general public.

title: SC told Immigration Controller’s affidavit prejudicial
author: BY Sandasen Marasinghe
Content: The Immigration Controller’s (IC) affidavit, submitted to the Court of Appeal, in connection with State Minister Diana Gamage’s passport, was prejudicial, the Supreme Court was told yesterday (12).  The Supreme Court Bench, comprising Justices Gamini Amarasekara, Kumuduni Wickremesinghe and Janak de Silva, was told that in an affidavit, after which he was transferred, Diana Gamage held a Sri Lankan passport, while another document had it that Diana Gamage was a British national.  President’s Counsel Farman Cassim submitted that the Immigration Controller continued to say in the affidavit that he (Immigration Controller) did not know if both referred to the same person, which was not at all his business.    Social activist Oshala Herath filed the appeal before the Supreme Court, when his petition before the Court of Appeal, challenging State Minister Gamage’s parliamentary membership, was ruled in a majority decision, that there were no merits in the writ petition which sought an order declaring that she is not qualified to be a Member of Parliament.  The petitioner sought from the Court of Appeal, an order in the nature of a Writ of Quo Warranto, declaring that Diana Gamage is disqualified to be a Member of Parliament and is thus not entitled to hold office as an MP. Counsel Hafeel Farisz appearing for the petitioner appellant, Herath, said that in a separate Court case in the Magistrate’s Court it was observed that there was ample evidence for the Police and Criminal Investigation Department (CID) to arrest Diana Gamage without a Court order.  Counsel Fariz submitted that that State Minister Diana Gamage is not a Sri Lankan. She has not obtained dual citizenship or any other form of citizenship in Sri Lanka. The hearing was postponed for today (13). Counsel Hafeel Farisz appeared for the petitioner. President’s Counsel Shavindra Fernando appeared for Diana Gamage. Farman Cassim PC appeared for the SJB General Secretary.

title: Maithripala leaves for the U.S.
author: Author not found
Content: Former President and incumbent leader of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) Maithripala Sirisena, left for the United States in the early hours of yesterday (12).  According to the SLFP sources, Sirisena boarded an Indian Airlines flight bound for New Delhi around 02.50 a.m. today, from where he is scheduled to continue his journey to the US. In related developments, political sources suggest that upon the return of the SLFP leader to the island, new appointments to the board the United People’s Freedom Alliance (UPFA) are expected. State Minister Lasantha Alagiyawanna is reportedly being considered for the position of UPFA General Secretary.

title: Medicinal drugs procured by SPC lie unclaimed in container yards
author: By Dilanthi Jayamanne
Content: Around 20 medicinal drug containers, imported through foreign suppliers, following accurate procurement procedures by the State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC), were lying unclaimed in container terminals in Kelaniya, Welisara and Wattala, medical trade unions alleged.  The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA), strongly condemned the Deputy Director General Medical Supplies Division (DDG MSD) and his Division for not talking responsibility for the detention of a number of medicinal drugs which had been imported to the country by the State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC) and was now languishing in a container terminal unclaimed. President MCPA, Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa yesterday (12) noted that the Health Ministry’s responsibility for the stock of imported pharmaceuticals should not be underestimated.  A large stock of medicinal drug imported through foreign suppliers, following accurate procurement procedures by the SPC, were lying in container terminals in Kelaniya, Welisara and Wattala. The Medicines were imported by the SPC in keeping with the procurement requests of the Health Ministry. Therefore, the Corporation is responsible for supplying the drugs from the moment they arrive in Sri Lanka to the Medical Supplies Division (MSD) while the latter should not forget its accountability for absorbing those medicines to the country’s health system as soon as possible.  Dr. Sanjeewa observed that the MSD should take urgent steps to reveal as to why the medicines were languishing in container terminals for about four months instead of being absorbed into the State health service. Also, a separate probe should be carried out to find if malpractices had occurred during the procurement process of those drugs. Also, relevant officials should be brought before the law if such malpractices had occurred, he said.   The MCPA President Further noted that the MSD was currently sans a permanent DDG to spear head it while the appointment of the Director of Lady Ridgeway Hospital for Children (LRH) as its ‘Acting DDG’ was not a feasible solution to the issue.    Dr. Sanjeewa said that Health Minister, Dr. Ramesh Pathirana should take urgent steps to remove all health officials who served under former Health Minister, Keheliya Rambukwella and appoint a new one in order to rebuild public trust in the state health system. Steps should be taken to remove officials appointed by the former Health Minister including the incumbent Director General of Health Services.

title: Police officer killed during arrest attempt posthumously promoted
author: Author not found
Content: Police Sergeant who was shot and had his weapon taken away, while trying to apprehend a suspect in Malwathu Hiripitiya, on 10 February, succumbed to his injuries at the National Hospital Colombo yesterday (12). The Sergeant was posthumously promoted to the rank of Sub-Inspector (SI), on the directive of Acting Inspector General of Police (IGP) Deshabandu Tennakoon, Police Spokesperson DIG Nihal Thalduwa said.  The incident occurred on Saturday (10) when a team of officers, from the Malwathu Hiripitiya Police Station, tried to apprehend a suspect in Batepola. A scuffle broke out, during which the suspect attempted to seize the officer’s firearm. In the struggle, the firearm discharged, injuring the 51-year-old Police officer, who hailed from Ihala Lunugama. The suspect then fled with the officer’s service firearm. The injured Police Sergeant was initially admitted to the Gampaha Hospital and later transferred to the Colombo National Hospital, where he succumbed to his injuries yesterday (12) morning.  Additionally, following details gathered regarding the incident, the Police Special Task Force (STF) successfully apprehended the suspect while he was in concealment at a residence in the Bingiriya. They seized the revolver belonging to the Police Sergeant, along with three 9mm bullets and the three-wheeler utilised by the suspect. Furthermore, a woman who assisted the suspect in evading capture has been taken into custody. The detained male suspect is identified as a 42-year-old resident of Wathuragama, while the female suspect is a 35-year-old resident of Udubaddawa.

title: Appellate Court dismisses State’s objections
author: BY Methmalie Dissanayake
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (12) dismissed objections raised by the State regarding two petitions concerning the deforestation of the Thrikonamadu Reserved Forest and the Sinharaja Forest Reserve. Environmentalists Hemantha Withanage, Dilena Pathragoda, and directors of the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) filed the petitions. The CEJ filed a petition against the construction of a road from Lankagama to Neluwa through the Sinharaja forest, on the directives of then-President Gotabaya Rajapaksa and another project to build several tanks within the Sinharaja forest. Respondents named in the petitions include the Conservator General, the Central Environmental Authority (CEA), the Minister of Wildlife and Forest Conservation, the Minister of Environment and the Attorney General. The Attorney General, representing the Respondents, raised objections to proceeding with the case, which the Appeal Court dismissed. Attorneys-at-Law Ravindranath Dabare, Samadhi Hansani Premasiri, Savanthi Ponnamperuma and Ishini Dilhara represented the petitioners. In a separate case, the Appeal Court issued notices to the Respondents in a petition filed by the CEJ against the deforestation of the Thrikonamadu Reserved Forest. The Respondents, including various government officials and agencies, raised objections to the continuation of the case, but the Court dismissed them and set the next hearing for 7 March. Attorneys-at-Law Ravindranath Dabare and Savanthi Ponnamperuma, on the instruction of Attorney-at-law Nilmal Wickremesinghe, represented the petitioners.

title: Number of cases with side effects after using cosmetics rising
author: By Dilanthi Jayamanne
Content: Against the backdrop of a rising number of cases visiting government hospitals with side effects resulting from the use of harmful cosmetic products, particularly among the youth, the regulation of such products entering the local market has become increasingly challenging.  This difficulty stems from the absence of regulations, notably the repeal of the Cosmetics, Devices, and Drugs Act, No. 27 (CDD Act), the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) alleged.  Without proper provisions in place to safeguard the public against harmful cosmetic products that are flooding the market, the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) held discussions with the Health Ministry Secretary to look into possibilities of tightening regulations to take proper and quick action against such harmful products.   GMOA Media Committee Member, Dr. Chamil Wijesinghe, when contacted, said the Health Ministry Secretary has identified the issue as a priority.  He said a follow up meeting was held yesterday (12) with the Sri Lanka College of Dermatologists (SLCD); Consultant Community Physicians met with the Public Health Subcommittee of the GMOA. Prior to 2015 the cosmetics were regulated under the Cosmetics, Devices and Drugs Act, No.27 (CDD Act). However, with the National Medicines Regulatory Act No.5 of 2015 being enacted in 2015, the CDD Act was abolished.  He noted however, that the NMRA had identified the urgent necessity to regulate the cosmetic products entering the local market. These products did not even fall into the borderline category. Hence, the Authority took measures to utilise the provisions given in the CDD Act.  Without even a proper place to register the cosmetics coming into the country, one cannot just utilise provisions of an act which has been abolished, he noted.  The GMOA Media Committee Member noted that the number of complaints reaching his outfit’s members, while serving in their respective hospitals and the number of cases coming to government hospitals with side effects – mostly from amongst the young, were increasing.  A sizable number of the products were harmful whitening creams and cosmetics which are not registered with any particular authority and had harmful effects which could cause allergies and even death to users.   Dr. Wijesinghe said that the situation was such that there were allegedly cosmetologists who allegedly specialise in the field of cosmetics when even the Post Graduate Institute of Medicine (PGIM) did not offer such specialised programmes. Some of them possess health background while there are none – health personnel who also practice as ‘Cosmetologists. These are quacks, he said.

title: HC Judge displeased with CIABOC’s conducting of evidence
author: BY Hansi Nanayakkara
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Adithya Patabendige yesterday (12) expressed his displeasure over the way in which the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) conducted the evidence, in a case filed against former North Central Province Chief Minister Ranjith Samarakoon.  Judge Patabendige said he was convinced that the hearing of evidence, in the case filed against Samarakoon and his Private Secretary, by the CIABOC, was being conducted sans any understanding of the charges. The Judge stated that the prosecution, was continuing to lead the evidence against the defendants, in a roundabout way, rather than getting to the point straightway and that he has no other option, but to reveal it, unfortunately. Accordingly Judge Patabendige, advised the prosecution to examine the case files well and lead the evidence, afterwards. He also stated that it was also the duty of the Prosecution, to justify to Court, if the second defendant (Private Secretary), had paid an additional sum for fuel and if how much and for how long. The Judge stated this, having suspended the hearing of evidence and deferred further hearing of the trial to 17 March. The CIABOC has charged the Former CM and his then Private Secretary, Shanthi Chandrasena, on eight counts over the misuse of Rs 2.5 million as fuel allowance, from 2012 to 2014 and for having flouted Provisions of the Bribery Act.

title: AG tells SC HC granting bail for suspects unacceptable
author: BY Sandasen Marasinghe
Content: The Attorney General submitted to the Supreme Court that the granting of bail to the 37 suspects, in the late MP Amarakeerthi Athukorala murder case, by the Gampaha High Court was not acceptable.    Deputy Solicitor General Janaka Bandara made this submission yesterday (12) before the Supreme Court Bench comprising Justices Padman Surasena, Yasantha Kodagoda and Mahinda Samayawardhena, when the appeal, challenging the granting of bail, by the Gampaha High Court Trial-at-Bar was taken up for hearing. DSG Bandara submitted that MP Athukorala was murdered on 9 May 2022 and 37 were remanded in connection with it. However, they were granted bail by the Trial-at-Bar at the Gampaha High Court on 8 July 2023. DSG stated that the Attorney General had not agreed to do so. Hence the Attorney General appealed against the decision of the Gampaha High Court.    President’s Counsel Saliya Peiris appearing for the suspects, submitted that the suspects had been in the remand custody for more than one year and the High Court considered that when granting bail.  The Court fixed the hearing for 9 July.

title: Asian Pigeonwings flowers a money spinner
author: BY Sumeda Karunaratne – Mihintale
Content: Flowers taken from the Asian Pigeonwings (Clitoria ternatea), in the villages in and around the Horowpatana Divisional Secretariat Division, including Maradankadawala have become a rich source of revenue both locally and overseas. This particular variety of flowers is being grown to beautify home gardens but for those in the aforementioned villages in the area it has emerged as a revenue earner. It is stated that this flower, which gives off a very aromatic smell, is also considered as an ayurvedic or herbal medicine capable of curing various ailments and this had led people cultivating it in large numbers in the said Divisional Secretariat Division. It is also said that due to the Asian Pigeonwings plant’s ability to cure various forms of ailments, it has gained a demand both locally and overseas. The plant is being cultivated sans the use of any fertiliser or pesticides whilst cultivators say that a kilo of flowers of this tree could be sold easily for a sum of Rs 3,000.

title: Rs2.5M for ‘Wings of Friendship’ project from UK’s Aerospace
author: Author not found
Content: CEO of ASL Aerospace in the UK, Brian Poulier, extended financial assistance in support of the ‘Wings of Friendship’ project, aligning with the 73rd Anniversary of the SLAF.  This endeavour consists of three sub-projects: renovating 73 deserving schools, donating 73,000 books to schoolchildren and planting 73,000 saplings in the Northern Province. The donation of Rs 2.5 million, was handed over to the Commander of the Air Force, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa at the Air Force Headquarters on 6 February 2024. The event was attended by ASL Aerospace’s sales directors, Varun Kapoor and Vajira Wickremasinghe, and Director General of Aeronautical Engineering and Head of the Organising Committee of the Education Exhibition and Air Tattoo 2024 Air Vice Marshal Muditha Mahawattege.

title: President visits former MP Gamini Jayawickrama Perera
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe visited the residence of former Minister Gamini Jayawickrama Perera, who is currently unwell, to inquire about his health. The President visited Perera’s home in Katugampala and engaged in a brief conversation with him to check on his well-being. President Wickremesinghe spoke to family members of Jayawickrama Perera, to find about his condition and offer support. The President also took this opportunity to interact with the local community near Jayawickrama Perera’s residence and exchange friendly conversations with the people of the area. Former Minister Akila Viraj Kariyawasam, and former North Western Provincial Council member Asanka Jayawickrama, who is the son of Gamini Jayawickrama Perera were among those present. Furthermore, several politicians from the Kurunegala district and Acting IGP Deshabandu Tennakoon also joined the President.

title: 45th National Freedom Day of Iran commemorated in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: The 45th National Freedom Day of Iran fell yesterday (11). The ceremony in Sri Lanka was organised at the Iranian Ambassador’s official residence in Colombo on 9 February. The chief guest was Irrigation, Wildlife and Forestry Minister Pavithra Wanniarachchi.  Addressing the ceremony Ambassador Dr Delkhosh said Iranian foreign policy is based on two aspects, one is to maintain economic cooperation among States and the other is to help strengthen the regional and global security. He also said acting against terrorism and the narcotic trade was paramount in the relations between the two countries. Dr Reiza further said Iran and Sri Lanka had diplomatic relations in the past and continue to do so in the present and that it was important for both countries to continue such relations with better understanding. He pointed out that Iran has achieved much in modern science and technology and hope to share such knowledge with Sri Lanka. The chief guest Minister Wanniarachchi said links between Sri Lanka and Iran have continued from the past and have immensely contributed to the economic and socio-cultural development of Sri Lanka. She said the mutual understanding and firm friendship between Sri Lankan President Ranil Wickremesinghe and his Iranian counterpart Dr. Zeid Ibrahim Reizi helped both countries to obtain many social, economic, cultural and political victories. The Minister also thanked the Iranian government for assisting in the recent debt restructuring process of Sri Lanka. She said construction activities of projects undertaken by the Iranian government including the Uma Oya multipurpose project continued even during the Covid-19 pandemic. Former Presidents Mahinda Rajapaksa, Gotabaya Rajapaksa, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana, State Minister of Foreign Affairs Taraka Balasuriya, several MPs and the top brass of the military were present.

title: University Entrance: GCE A/L to become redundant
author: By Paneetha Ameresekere
Content: The present GCE A/L (General Certificate of Education Advanced Level) and GCE O/L (Ordinary Level) exams will be archaic under the proposed education reforms  The Education Ministry in an upload, on its website yesterday, of a document titled ‘National Education Policy Framework Sri Lanka’ (NEPF) said that instead, mandatory school completion certificates at Grades 11 and 12+ will come to the fore.  “Less weightage shall be placed on final, summative examinations such as GCE O/L and GCE A/L by making them optional. Increased emphasis will be placed on formative assessment of projects, assignments and portfolios of co-curricular or extra-curricular work to be captured through completion certificates,” the report said. Those who leave school after Senior Secondary- (Years 10-11; Ages 14-16/GCE O/L) stage shall have the opportunity for re-entry to further education and training through a Senior Secondary-II (Year 12+; Ages 16-18/GCE A/L) stage completion certificate equivalent, making them eligible to enter State universities, the report said.  “All students completing Year 11 or Year 12+ will be awarded a completion certificate capturing the full extent of their learning at school during those years,” it added.  No delays in moving from “Year 11 to Year 12+” or “12+ to tertiary education. “All students will be promoted based on their completion certificates without having to wait for the results of national examinations (O/L and A/L),” the report added.   Mandatory Minimum Proficiency Requirements: Minimum proficiency in literacy, numeracy and digital literacy and completion of school-based curricular, co-curricular and extra- curricular assignments are mandatory for receiving a completion certificate.   All students will be promoted based on their completion certificates without having to wait for the results of national examinations (O/L and A/L), it further said.  “Once approved by the Cabinet/ Parliament, the draft NEPF (2023-2033) as this document is known will provide the directions and guidance for the implementation of education reforms during that period,” the report said.

title: Appeals open for admission to Grade six classes

title: Dayasiri further restrained
author: BY Hansi Nanayakkara
Content: Colombo District Court Judge Sandun Vithana, yesterday further extended the injunction, imposed on ousted Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) General Secretary, MP Dayasiri Jayasekera, till 28 February. As per the injunction the former General Secretary, has been barred from interfering in any way with the party and its administrative, organisational and political activities of its Acting General Secretary, MP Sarathi Dushmantha Mithrapala. The Court extended the injunction, having perused a petition, filed by SLFP Leader MP Maithripala Sirisena and the Acting General Secretary. They had petitioned the Court, stating that Jayasekera had spread misleading information, among party faithful, alleging that upon a favourable verdict, being issued by Court, he would promptly resume his work as the party General Secretary.

title: India’s view not pertinent to NPP stance – Vijitha
author: BY Methmalie Dissanayake
Content: During the recent visit to India, the primary focus of discussions with the Indian Government revolved around regional security, said NPP MP Vijitha Herath in a media debriefing at Party Headquarters in Pelawatta.  The delegation concluded its five-day visit to India and held a media briefing at the JVP Headquarters in Pelawatta yesterday (11). Responding to a query, Herath explained, “The main focus of our discussions centred on regional security, particularly in South Asia. We deliberated on various geopolitical threats that could potentially undermine regional stability. We assured our Indian counterparts that we are committed to safeguarding regional security while upholding our nation’s sovereignty. It’s imperative to note that our national security measures inherently contribute to regional security.” Regarding diplomatic relations with China, Herath clarified that India did not impose any restrictions or directives on maintaining ties with China. He emphasised that such matters are not pertinent to the NPP’s stance. When asked if the discussions with India would impact the NPP’s relations with China, Herath underscored that the party has a history of engaging with both India and China. He reaffirmed the NPP’s consistent stance on maintaining connections with various countries while safeguarding the national interest. For instance, he highlighted the NPP’s opposition to the previous government’s decision to lease the Hambantota Port to China, emphasising that their political stance remains unwavering regardless of discussions held with India or China. Herath said the trip was not an impromptu one but had in response to an invitation received last December. However, due to their tight, they had postponed it until February, ultimately reducing the visit from the initially planned ten days to five. He explained that India had initially extended a ten-day invitation, but the NPP opted to curtail it due to their prior commitments and internal party activities. He highlighted that this wasn’t the NPP’s maiden diplomatic invitation, citing a previous visit by NPP Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake and a delegation to China, albeit with less publicity compared to the latest India visit. We vehemently opposed such efforts to safeguard our sovereignty. However, the political landscape has undergone significant change since then. Presently, our country faces economic challenges, and it is imperative that we rebuild both economically and politically with a clear vision.” Responding to queries regarding any assurances or support from India for future elections, Herath categorically stated that no such discussions had taken place, emphasising that countries endorse democratically elected governments rather than political parties vying for power. Regarding the NPP’s stance on Indian investors like Adani and Amul, Herath said their protest centered around the selection of investors through unsolicited proposals. He reiterated that an NPP administration would welcome investors from any nation but stressed the importance of transparent investment processes and adherence to due tender procedures. Reflecting on the visit’s outcomes, Herath deemed it successful and hinted at implementing several lessons learnt from the trip should an NPP government come to power.

title: Veiled attempts to delay polls will be thwarted
author: BY Methmalie Dissanayake
Content: Former President Maithripala Sirisena said the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) would support a proposal to abolish the Executive Presidency in the country.  Addressing a media brief organised by the SLFP titled ‘We Stand for Freedom’ (‘Nidahasa Wenuwen Api’), the former President disclosed that plans were in motion to introduce such a proposal in the near future, based on information received. Premadasa reiterated that while the SJB maintains its stance on the abolition of the Executive Presidency, it will not tolerate any actions that infringe the people’s mandate and their right to vote. He emphasised the importance of upholding the democratic process, affirming that both the presidential and general elections scheduled for 2024 must proceed as planned.

title: PUCSL to determine next date of electricity tariff revision – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: The date of the next electricity tariff revision will be determined by the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL), Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said.  At a media briefing on Saturday (10), Minister Wijesekera said, as the Minister, he does not have the authority to make decisions regarding electricity tariff revisions instead, he could only submit proposals to the PUCSL. “We can submit the proposal to the PUCSL, and they will initiate the process of collecting public opinions. title: SL produces its largest pizza
author: By T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake
Content: To celebrate World Pizza Day on 9 February, TukTuk Wine & Dine in Negombo embarked on a challenge to create the largest pizza in Sri Lanka.
