title: ‘For me to be back, I must contest’
author: Author not found
Content: With the presidential race heating up and regional dynamics constantly evolving, President Ranil Wickremesinghe, in an interview with Indian news channel WION, said both the Presidential and General Elections would take place this year. He also exuded confidence about his chances of securing re-election in the upcoming Presidential Polls.  The interview, conducted during Wickremesinghe’s participation at the 7th Indian Ocean Conference in Perth, Australia, also saw him address growing concerns regarding China’s expanding influence in the region. Wickremesinghe expressed optimism about facing the electoral challenge, highlighting his commitment to addressing the nation’s ongoing economic and political turmoil. However, his most significant remarks came on the topic of China’s presence in the Indian Ocean. Recognising the importance of Sri Lanka’s relationship with India, Wickremesinghe offered strong assurances that his nation wouldn’t tolerate any activities detrimental to India’s security.  He emphasised, “We’ve kept Indian security in mind and we will not allow anything to happen that will be harmful to Indian security.” Further clarifying Sri Lanka’s recent decision to deny entry to Chinese vessels, Wickremesinghe explained that the move was based on the Government’s strategic focus on building its own hydrographic capabilities. He stressed that the decision wasn’t specifically targeted at China and that visits by naval vessels would still be permitted. This explanation aims to ease tensions and maintain cordial relations with both India and China, key players in the regional geopolitical landscape.  Following are excerpts of the interview: WION: And moving forward to the domestic aspects of your country. Elections (are) happening this year. Wickremesinghe: Yes, both presidential and parliamentary. WION: And, how optimistic are you that hopefully you will (be) back. Wickremesinghe: For me to be back, I must contest. WION: And do you plan to sir? Wickremesinghe: I have come here to put the economy (right). My first duty is to focus on that. We (need to) get out of bankruptcy. WION: And do you think you’ve done a good job? I mean, what’s your view about the economy in terms of your tenure because you ultimately were the face of the crisis in terms of the emergence of Sri Lanka (back to normalcy)? Wickremesinghe: Well, I’m quite satisfied. I feel we will be able to do this. WION: You will be able to do this. Another thing is the implementation of the 13th Amendment, something that India has also been talking about. What’s the way forward? Wickremesinghe: (We will) hold the Provincial Council Election next year. As I announced in my speech, when I opened Parliament, we want to give each province its own economy. So, like in India, economies will compete with each other, which is to benefit, or to be very, very competitive economies. And those provinces should handle their economic and social development within the National Policy Framework. In this respect, we said we are prepared to give the concurrent powers, most of it, or whatever is required, whatever they want, to the provincial councils, so that we are moving on. There has been a request by some of the groups for minority groups (in) our Senate. So, as far as we are concerned, we will not oppose it, but it’s a matter for all parties to agree to, not merely the Government, and there are so many parties in Parliament at present.  (MD)

title: Prez Fund reaches out to children
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has instructed the allocation of financial aid from the President’s Fund to cover the expenses of liver transplant surgeries for young children at the Ragama Teaching Hospital and cochlear implant surgeries at the Sri Jayewardenepura General Hospital. The decision, as conveyed by the President’s Media Division (PMD), aims to ease the financial burden on underprivileged parents and prioritise the welfare of children, recognising their significance for the nation’s future. Acknowledging the significant expenses involved in pre and post-tests and treatments for liver transplant surgeries in children under 16 years old at the North Colombo General Hospital (Ragama Teaching Hospital), President Wickremesinghe has approved Rs 1 million from the President’s Fund for each liver transplant surgery meeting specified criteria. This financial support will take effect from 1 January 2024, intending to relieve families undergoing these critical medical procedures from financial stress, according to the PMD. President Wickremesinghe’s directive underscores the government’s dedication to providing essential medical care for children in need, particularly those facing life-threatening conditions requiring specialized surgeries. By utilising the President’s Fund to facilitate these surgeries, the Gaims to ensure that financial constraints do not hinder access to crucial healthcare services for young patients, thus safeguarding their health and future well-being. It has been observed through medical assessments that over 200 children in Sri Lanka are in need of cochlear implant surgery, essential for their auditory development. While such surgeries are promptly conducted at birth upon identification of the need in developed countries, in Sri Lanka, not all eligible children undergo this procedure due to financial constraints. Medical experts stress the importance of performing such operations within two years from birth for optimal brain development. However, the estimated cost, exceeding Rs. 5 million, poses a significant barrier. Presently, this surgery is only available at a few government hospitals, resulting in waiting lists for affected children. The cochlear implant surgery is performed at the Sri Jayawardenepura General Hospital, with the implant device valued at approximately Rs. 3-4 million. While the Ministry of Health provides the device to the hospital free of charge, patients are required to cover the surgery costs, amounting to Rs 600,000. Recognising the financial burden, the Ministry of Health has procured the necessary cochlear implant devices. Additionally, the surgery costs, totaling Rs 600,000, will be covered by the President’s Fund. Consequently, the government will bear the expenses associated with these surgeries, conducted at the Sri Jayawardenepura General Hospital. The decision to provide financial aid from the President’s Fund for cochlear implant surgeries for these children is not only a societal benefit but also eases the strain on the healthcare system. Despite the substantial financial investment required, it must be understood that supporting these surgeries for young children is an investment in the nation’s future. As a result, President Ranil Wickremesinghe has authorised financial assistance from the President’s Fund, effective 1 January 2024, with a maximum amount of Rs 600,000 for cochlear implant surgeries conducted on children at the Sri Jayawardenepura General Hospital.

title: Rs 9B to support paddy procurement programme
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture, Mahinda Amaraweera said, the Government will allocate Rs 9 billion to support small and medium rice mill owners, paddy collectors and paddy warehouse owners through subsidised interest rates for the paddy procurement programme. Meanwhile, the Government will blacklist small and medium-scale rice millers, paddy collectors and paddy warehouse owners and connected entities if they fail to procure paddy stocks from farmers at the minimum prices mandated by the Government, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said. To facilitate the purchase of paddy from farmers, the Government has arranged for loans through various State and commercial banks at concessional interest rates. Further, the minimum price for paddy has been established to ensure significant benefits for farmers. Amaraweera emphasised the importance of setting a minimum price for paddy this year to safeguard the interests of farmers and consumers. He said traders were purchasing paddy from farmers at prices ranging from Rs 70 to Rs 80 per kilogramme.

title: CID arrests convicted woman after 35 years
author: Author not found
Content: A woman who had been evading the authorities for 35 years following her involvement in a murder case and subsequent death sentence, was apprehended by the Homicide and Organised Crime Investigation Unit of the CID.  The incident dates back to 1989 when the Borella Police initiated an investigation into the murder of a quality inspector from the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) in Wellawa, Athurugiriya. The investigation was prompted by a complaint filed by the deceased’s wife. Subsequent investigations led to the arrest of a couple residing in Wellawa, Athurugiriya. It was revealed that the woman, then aged 30 and employed as an English stenographer at the CEB, had allegedly been in a romantic relationship with the deceased. Allegedly, after her husband found out about the clandestine relationship, the woman lured her lover to their residence in Wellawa, Athurugiriya, where, together with her husband, she committed the murder. The victim’s body was dismembered, placed in a barrel and dumped into a well. The couple was remanded for six months before being released on bail.  Subsequently, they went into hiding and were sentenced to death in absentia in 2019 following a trial conducted in their absence. Acting on information received, the CID located the woman, now 64-years-old and a mother of one, hiding in a rented house in the Bandaragama, Pamunugama  The woman admitted to living away from her husband out of fear of being apprehended by the authorities. However, her husband remains at large. The suspect appeared before the Homagama Magistrate on Saturday (10) and was remanded until today (12).

title: OSA targets only those misusing social media – Minister Alles
author: By Methmalie Dissanayake
Content: During a Community Police initiative, Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles, announced the arrest of an individual accused of online slander, based on instructions and support of a politician. Minister Alles said the suspect had approximately Rs 400,000 in his possession at the time of the arrest and allegedly confessed to receiving support from a politician for defamatory social media campaigns against several individuals including himself. The Minister emphasised the Government’s stance against online abuse and highlighted the recently enacted Online Safety Act. He claimed the suspect targeted not only himself and the Government but also the Acting IGP and others. He further expressed concerns about the potential misuse of social media to destabilise the Government. “The CID arrested an individual engaged in online defamation through social media platforms. The suspect alleged receiving money from a politician. The arrest occurred immediately after the suspect attempted to exchange US dollars for Sri Lankan rupees in Fort. Their online activities targeted various entities, including the Government, the Acting IGP and others,” Minister Alles stressed.  However, the Minister did not disclose any more information about the suspect.  “Those who misuse social media are now scared of the Online Safety Act. Some people (who are) overseas use social media as a cat’s paw to carry out their own agendas. They want to make the country collapse by promoting drug deals and underworld activities.” The Minister reiterated that the Online Safety Act targets only those who misuse social media and aims to curb harmful online activities. The Online Safety Act proposes jail terms for content that a five-member commission appointed by the President considers illegal and makes social media platforms such as Alphabet’s Google (GOOGL.O), Meta’s Facebook (META.O) and X, formerly known as Twitter, liable for such content on their platforms. The commission members have not been appointed so far.

title: Visible drop in air quality – NBRO
author: Author not found
Content: The National Building Research Organization (NBRO) has issued a warning regarding the deteriorating air quality in several parts of the island, emphasising that it has reached unhealthy levels. According to the NBRO, apart from Nuwara Eliya, the air quality in all other districts is classified as unhealthy, with Colombo, Kandy and Jaffna experiencing particularly high levels of pollution. The NBRO further cautioned that based on the US Air Quality Index (AQI), the air quality in Colombo, Kilinochchi, Jaffna, Trincomalee, Badulla, Kurunegala, Kandy and Matale is likely to have adverse health effects.  Attributing this decline in air quality to an increase in dust particles carried by strong winds from neighboring countries and the prevailing extreme dry weather conditions, the NBRO urged individuals with respiratory or cardiac conditions, as well as elderly persons and children, to wear face masks when outdoors.

title: Launch of UPI services in Sri Lanka, Mauritius
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Indian Premier Narendra Modi and the Prime Minister of Mauritius Pravind Jugnauth will witness the launch of Unified Payment Interface(UPI) services in Sri Lanka and Mauritius, and also RuPay card services in Mauritius, today (12) at 1.00 p.m. via video conferencing.  India has emerged as a leader in Fintech innovation and Digital Public Infrastructure.  The Premier has emphasised the need to share development experiences and innovation with partner countries.  Given India’s robust cultural and people-to-people linkages with Sri Lanka and Mauritius, the launch will benefit a wide cross-section of people through a faster and seamless digital transaction experience and enhance digital connectivity between the countries, Indian High Commission in Sri Lanka, said in a statement.   The launch will enable availability of UPI settlement services for Indian nationals travelling to Sri Lanka and Mauritius as well as for Mauritian nationals travelling to India. The extension of RuPay card services in Mauritius will enable Mauritian banks to issue cards based on RuPay mechanism in Mauritius and facilitate usage of RuPay Card for settlements both in India and Mauritius, the High Commission added.

title: Gunmen on mobike fatally shoot 60-year-old
author: Author not found
Content: Police said suspects riding a motorcycle are believed to have been involved in the recent shooting incident in Galkanda, Negombo. Police reported that the motorcycle was found abandoned in Seeduwa, along with a helmet and jacket. The incident occurred around 7.00 p.m. on Saturday (10) where two unidentified gunmen fatally shot a man at Galkanda Junction in Negombo. title: TN Chief Minister calls for release of Indian fishermen
author: Author not found
Content: Urging the Centre to expedite its diplomatic efforts in securing the release of fishermen apprehended by Sri Lankan authorities, Tamil Nadu Chief Minister M.K. Stalin expressed concerns about the increase in attacks on members of the State’s fishing community in the region and urged Prime Minister Narendra Modi to intervene and resolve the issue at the earliest, Indian media reported.  In his letter to Prime Minister Modi, Chief Minister Stalin stated, “I am writing to express my deep concern regarding the alarming increase in incidents of apprehension of Tamil fishermen and their boats by the Sri Lankan authorities. This issue severely impacts the right to livelihood of these fishermen, as the communities have utilised these fishing waters for generations.” CM Stalin urged Prime Minister Modi to renew the Joint Action Group to resolve fishermen’s issues. He also highlighted a ‘significant increase’ in the number of fishermen being arrested. “The traditional fishing waters that Tamil fishermen have relied upon for generations are getting increasingly restricted, making it difficult to sustain their livelihood impacting the economic stability of these communities. This also threatens the cultural and social fabric of the region that revolves around the fishing industry. During 2023, the Sri Lankan Navy arrested 243 fishermen and seized 37 boats. However, in the past 28 days alone, 88 fishermen and 12 boats were apprehended in six incidents,” CM Stalin wrote. He mentioned that a legislation recently passed in Sri Lanka allows the country to nationalise the seized boats, which could drive members of the State’s fishing community into penury. “I had previously addressed you regarding the amendment made to the Fisheries Act by the Government of Sri Lanka in 2018, which enables the Sri Lankan Government to nationalise foreign fishing vessels. Due to this action of Sri Lanka, the seized fishing boats of our fishermen that are in good condition cannot be salvaged and brought back to Tamil Nadu. Many fishermen have invested their life savings in acquiring and maintaining their boats, which are vital for their trade,” he wrote while urging the Sri Lankan government to make necessary amendments to the law. CM Stalin also requested Prime Minister Modi to ensure that “all-out diplomatic efforts should be made to secure the release of 77 fishermen and their 151 boats from Sri Lanka”.

title: Contraband used for organised crimes found

Content: The Special Task Force (STF) conducted a search operation within the Boossa Prison on 10 February and contraband including mobile phones in the possession of inmates were found. title: Customs seizes gold valued at Rs 58M
author: BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake
Content: Officials from the Narcotics Control Unit of Sri Lanka Customs intercepted a stash of gold jewellery and gold in gel form valued at approximately Rs 58 million. The contraband was being smuggled out of the BIA by an employee of a private cleaning company. The gold was seized on Saturday morning (10), with the apprehended individual being identified as a 55-year-old resident of Miridiyalanda in Veyangoda. The suspect admitted to Sri Lanka Customs that an unidentified woman had entrusted her with the parcel containing the gold inside a toilet at the duty-free mall area of the BIA. She stated that the woman had promised her Rs 60,000 on delivering the parcel to someone outside the airport premises. The confiscated gold includes 1.4kg of gold jewellery and 1.35kg of gold in gel form, with an approximate purity of 95%, as confirmed by a spokesperson for the Narcotics Control Unit of Sri Lanka Customs. Sri Lanka Customs have launched an investigation into the incident.

title: ‘Cat Walk 2024’ at Galle Face Hotel
author: Author not found
Content: ‘Cat Walk 2024’ by Saudi Ambassador Khalid bin Hamoud Alkahtani took place at the Galle Face Hotel in Colombo, commemorating the International Day of the Arabian Leopard. This day was designated by the United Nations General Assembly on 12 June 2023. The resolution, titled ‘International Arabian Leopard Day’, was proposed by Saudi Arabia and supported by over 30 countries. Its objective is to raise awareness about the endangered status of the Arabian leopard, among other big cat species like lions, tigers, jaguars and cheetahs. The resolution emphasises the importance of wildlife preservation and biodiversity conservation. The event featured a stroll along Galle Face Beach, showcasing Colombo’s tourist attractions. Several senior ministers, government officials, heads of Arab countries’ missions accredited to Sri Lanka, prominent media personalities, embassy staff and their families participated in the event. The Arabian leopard (Panthera pardus nimr) is a critically endangered leopard subspecies that inhabits the Arabian Peninsula. It is one of the smallest leopard subspecies, with an average weight of 30-40 kg for males and 25-35 kg for females. Its fur is pale and buff-colored with rosettes that are small and closely spaced. The Arabian leopard has a very limited distribution, being found only in a few isolated pockets of habitat in Saudi Arabia, Oman, Yemen and the United Arab Emirates. Estimates suggest there may be fewer than 200 Arabian leopards left in the wild. Threats to the species include urbanisation, farming, overgrazing by livestock, poaching, and the illegal wildlife trade. Conservation efforts focus on habitat protection, restoration of natural prey populations, and public education programmes to reduce human-leopard conflict. The Arabian leopard is legally protected across its range, but greater enforcement of laws and active management of surviving populations are needed to ensure the species’ survival.

title: Elderly man dies in fatal mobike collision
author: By Naalir Jamaldeen
Content: An elderly man who was knocked down by a motorcycle last (11) morning on the Kachchay – Puloli Road in Vadamarachchi died on the spot, Point Pedro Police said. Police said the victim was spreading paddy on the roadside to dry along the Kachchay – Puloli Road in Vadamarachchi when the motorbike travelling toward Kachchay hit him. Preliminary investigations revealed that due to misty conditions the motorcyclist could hardly see anything coming in his direction and collided with the victim resulting in his death. However, the motorcyclist escaped without any injury.  The body was taken to the Point Pedro Base Hospital, where Coroner S. Sivarajah conducted post-mortem. After the post-mortem, the body was handed over to relatives for funeral rites.

title: SL tops S-Asia in electricity rates
author: Author not found
Content: As of this week, Sri Lanka stands out in South Asia for having the highest electricity rates, with households paying 2.5 – 3 times more than the average prices seen in other South Asian nations, according to a recent analysis. The analysis, featured on PublicFinance.lk, a platform for economic insights in Sri Lanka, was conducted by Verité Research. It examined the electricity charges for households consuming 100, 200 or 300 units at the beginning of 2024, focusing solely on supplier rates and excluding government taxes like the Social Security Levy in Sri Lanka. Comparatively, the second-highest household electricity costs in the region are found in Pakistan, although they remain considerably lower than those of Sri Lanka. For instance, households consuming 100 units face charges that are 50 per cent higher in Sri Lanka than in Pakistan, while those consuming 300 units are confronted with rates that are 97 per cent higher in Sri Lanka. The surge in Sri Lanka’s electricity charges follows a commitment made to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) programme, wherein the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) pledged to recoup its full costs through a combination of consumer charges and subsidies from the Treasury. Despite a slated tariff reduction this month (February 2024) is expected to decrease electricity charges by four per cent or less, the impact is deemed inconsequential. Consequently, Sri Lankan households are poised to persist as the region’s highest payers for electricity by a significant margin.

title: Don’t trust Finance Ministry data, figures
author: BY Methmalie Dissanayake
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Mahindananda Aluthagamage, making a strong statement in Parliament yesterday (8), warned the Government not to trust the data and figures provided by the Ministry of Finance.  Aluthgamage, participating in the Adjournment Debate on the Government Policy Statement made by President Ranil Wickremesinghe on Wednesday (7), expressed reservations regarding the accuracy of data and figures provided by the Finance Ministry.  He urged the President, Government officials and the Cabinet to exercise caution in relying on information from the Ministry of Finance. Speaking further, Aluthgamage stressed the importance of thorough scrutiny, citing instances where Ministry officials themselves admitted to submitting erroneous data to the International Monetary Fund (IMF).  Additionally, there is a significant discrepancy of one trillion rupees between the data presented by the Ministry of Finance and the figures intended for use in the recent policy statement in Parliament, he alleged and stressed that the President should decide whether these officials should be at the ministry any further.

title: State revenue increases by 25% following VAT – Siyambalapitiya
author: BY Methmalie Dissanayake
Content: State revenue surged by 25 per cent in January following the VAT increase, reaching Rs 274 billion, surpassing the estimated revenue of Rs 219 billion, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said yesterday (8).  He disclosed that the Customs exceeded its target by recording Rs 121 billion, 11 per cent higher than the estimated revenue of Rs 114 billion for January. Similarly, the Excise Department’s revenue of Rs 14 billion exceeded the target of Rs 12 billion. Moreover, the Inland Revenue Department surpassed its target by Rs 88.9 billion, achieving Rs 114 billion. Addressing Parliament during the adjournment debate on government policy, State Minister Siyambalapitiya emphasised that despite concerns over potential price hikes due to the VAT increase, January’s inflation stood at 6.4 per cent, with food inflation at a mere 3.3 per cent. He attributed this to the exemption of essential commodities from VAT. Non-food inflation was recorded at 7.9 per cent. Speaking further, Siyambalapitiya said, the increase in State revenue will ultimately benefit all citizens of the country.

title: NPP Leader’s India visit signals positive shift – UNP
author: By Naalir Jamaldeen
Content: National People’s Power (NPP) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake’s visit to India signals a positive shift to their (NPP/ JVP) movement towards modern global politics, transcending their traditional political ideologies, UNP Chairman MP Wajira Abeywardena stated yesterday (8). Abeywardena, addressing a media briefing at Sirikotha, remarked that such evolution within the JVP should be embraced, despite their previous stand against India.  He noted that their favourable remarks about the President clearly indicate their acceptance of his political and economic policies.  He also emphasised that these developments signify the JVP’s progression towards a globally accepted modern geopolitical framework, departing from their historical ideologies. Highlighting the need for change within the party, Abeywardena recalled their past ministerial roles, including positions in Agriculture, Fisheries, Cultural Affairs and Industry Ministries. Expressing his contentment with the JVP’s transformation, MP Abeywardena claimed it is a positive sign to see them adapting to modern political culture.  Abeywardena claimed that Dissanayake’s activities align with President Wickremesinghe’s political and economic agenda, particularly in combating corruption, reducing unnecessary expenditure and streamlining State expenses. He recounted the JVP’s history of socialisation, citing instances under President J.R. Jayewardene in 1977 and President D.B. Wijetunge in 1993. Abeywardena noted that the JVP’s political influence grew, leading to the establishment of governments. Speaking further he remarked, that even MPs who faced imprisonment during ‘Good Governance’ Government President Wickremesinghe now, except for Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, who served as a minister in that government.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: President brainwashed NPP – Minister de Silva
author: BY Methmalie Dissanayake
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva yesterday (8) claimed that it was President Ranil Wickremesinghe who ‘brainwashed’ the National People’s Power (NPP) to engage with Indian leaders. Speaking in Parliament, the Minister remarked, “Those who once lectured on Indian expansionism are now meeting with Indian leaders.  They, who previously donned worn-out attire, now don full suits. We view this development positively, attributing it to Ranil Wickremesinghe’s influence.” Speaking further, de Silva recalled past criticism from these leaders regarding the government’s involvement in business ventures with the Adani Group in India.  “They are now even meeting Indian investors. It is a very good thing. Also, they have to praise the India as well. This is how President Wickremesinghe brainwashed them,” the minister stressed.

title: Request to include ‘Malayaga Tamilar’ in the Census
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: A delegation representing the upcountry Tamils of Indian Origin, also known as Malayaga Thamilar, visited the National Census and Statistics office, to present a petition signed by 35,000 individuals, urging for the recognition of their ethnicity in the national census. The group emphasised that by acknowledging their distinct identity and historical contributions, they aim to uphold the integrity of Sri Lanka’s diverse society, strengthen collective heritage and reaffirm their commitment to national progress and unity. With a heritage spanning over two centuries, the Malayaga Tamilar community takes pride in their significant contributions to various sectors of the country’s economy and social fabric, including commerce, industry, and the arts. Their rich literary tradition and unique cultural practices reflect their unique identity.  The petition was submitted to the Director-General of the Department of National Census and Statistics, Chandani Bandara.

title: NPP delegation tours i-Hub Gujarat
author: Author not found
Content: National People’s Power (NPP) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake and his delegation embarked on a tour of i-Hub Gujarat, a renowned Gujarat Student Startup and Innovation Hub. During their visit to Ahmedabad, Dissanayake was engaged with officials of i-Hub Gujarat, exploring the institute’s facilities and initiatives. i-Hub Gujarat serves as an Innovation Hub offering consultancy services, laboratory access, and infrastructure support to students and entrepreneurs, while also facilitating investment opportunities. Additionally, the delegation had the opportunity to tour the Gujarat Agro Industries Corporation (GAIC), TATA Motors and a solar power plant situated in Ahmedabad. As their Indian visit drew to a close, Dissanayake and the delegation departed for Trivandrum in Kerala yesterday (8) night.

title: Jagath Priyankara sworn in as MP
author: Author not found
Content: Jagath Priyankara was sworn in, as a member of the Ninth Parliament, before Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana yesterday (8). Following the taking oaths before the Speaker, he signed the Members’ Roll kept before Secretary General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera.  Jagath Priyankara has been appointed to the vacancy created by the demise of Sanath Nishantha, who served as an MP representing the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) from the Puttalam District. Born in 1979, Jagath Priyankara completed his primary education at Dikwela Primary School and his secondary education at Joseph Vas College, Wennappuwa. He is also a Bachelor of Arts Graduate from the University of Kelaniya. Priyankara, who contested under the Eksath Janatha Nidahas Sandhanaya at the 2015 general election, was the fifth in the district obtaining 31,424 preferential votes. Again in 2017, he contested the Local Government Election under SLPP and was elected as one of its members. Contesting under Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna at the 2020 General Election, he secured 40,724 votes and was sixth in the district. He is a Samurdhi manager by profession and also the convener of the Samurdhi National Organisation Centre. Priyankara is the son of the late L.K. Samson Jayantha who worked as a journalist in the Dinamina, Lankadeepa and Mawbima newspapers and social and political activist. Priyankara, who is married to M.V Dedunu in 2007, is the father of three children.

title: Abducted doctor rescued , kidnapper arrested
author: BY S. Deeyagahage – Ahangama
Content: A specialist doctor, attached to the Teaching Hospital Badulla, who was kidnapped and held in captivity by a tuition master in Galle demanding a ransom of Rs 4 million, was rescued by Hikkaduwa Police, according to Deputy Inspector General’s (DIG) office in Galle.  The doctor was held captive in a house in Thelwatta, Meetiyagoda.  According to the Police, the 28-year-old tuition master, a resident of Meetiyagoda had been arrested. The Police stated that initial inquiries conduced into the incident revealed that the suspect tuition master had given a phone call to the doctor and misled him into coming to Meetiyagoda. Later, the suspect kidnapped the doctor and held him in captivity for over 48-hours. He then threatened the doctor claiming that he killed three persons on previous occasions and demanded money.  However, following a tip off, the Officer-in-Charge of Hikkaduwa Police deployed a team to locate the house, via GPS, where the suspect detained the doctor and they arrested the suspect.

title: Police nab 42 suspects in public transport
author: By Buwanaka S. Perera
Content: Following the islandwide special operation launched on Wednesday (7) by Sri Lanka Police, 42 suspects have been arrested for sexually harassing children and women in public transport.  The four-hour-long operation, which was conducted between 8.00 a.m. and 10.00 a.m. and 5.00 p.m. and 7.00 p.m. by Police officers clad in civvies, was carried out  on the instructions of Acting Inspector General of Police Deshabandu Tennakoon. Police said that along with the  42 suspects who were arrested, five pickpockets were also arrested. Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles recently told media that the operation was launched as a move to address the increasing number of complaints received at Police Stations with regard to sexual harassment incidents faced by women and children in public transport. Police introduced hotline 109 to report crimes against women and children. The Sri Lanka Police commenced a 24-hour public complaints desk and hotline to receive complaints relating to crimes committed against women and children, recently.

title: Kiriella accuses Govt of plotting to postpone Presidential Poll
author: BY Methmalie Dissanayake
Content: Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella yesterday (8) accused the Government of hatching ‘sinister plots’ to delay the Presidential Election, which should be held this year.  Speaking in Parliament, Kiriella highlighted the absence of any mention of the Presidential Election in the President’s Government Policy statement.  “The President did not mention about holding a Presidential Election this year in the Policy Statement. This is very suspicious.”  Therefore, we suspect that there may be intentions to propose the abolition of the executive presidency, a move that could lead to a postponement of the election,” he stressed.  Kiriella asserted that if the government proposes abolishing the executive presidency, they may argue the need for a new Constitution, which could take at least a year to formulate. He expressed apprehension that these manoeuvres could pave the way for a further one-year delay in holding the Presidential Election.

title: SLRCS Galle Branch named Social Service Provider of the Year once more
author: Author not found
Content: The country’s largest humanitarian organisation, Sri Lanka Red Cross Society’s (SLRCS) Galle Branch was honoured with a prestigious title for the second consecutive year as the Top Performing Social Service Provider in the Galle District for the year 2023. The recognition was bestowed at the esteemed Galu Disa Prawardana – Annual Performances Appraisal 2023, in appreciation of the outstanding community development projects implemented in the district. For two consecutive years, the Galle Branch of the SLRCS has spearheaded impactful initiatives that have positively impacted the lives of countless individuals in the Galle District. Their unwavering dedication and commitment to serving the community, have demonstrated excellence in delivering essential humanitarian aid and fostering sustainable development. Director General of the SLRCS, Dr. Mahesh Gunasekara, proudly expressed his heartfelt congratulations to the Galle Branch for their remarkable achievement. He added: “We are extremely proud of our Galle Branch for their exceptional performance and unwavering commitment to serving humanity. Providing the best to our communities during the toughest times is not an easy task. Their dedication and constant efforts in improving the lives of vulnerable communities marks the true spirit of humanitarianism.” “We are deeply honoured to receive this prestigious award for the second consecutive year. This achievement is a testament to the hard work and the dedication of our volunteers and staff, who work tirelessly to make a positive impact in the lives of those in need,” added SLRCS’s Galle Branch Chairman, Upali Sirimanne, expressing gratitude for the recognition and the collaborative efforts of the branch’s volunteers and staff. SLRCS’s Galle Branch has been at the forefront during the dire circumstances of the district, during adverse weather conditions, flood situations, with school feeding programmes and more. The organisation remains committed to its mission of alleviating human suffering and promoting community resilience. Established in 1936, the Sri Lanka Red Cross Society has evolved from its origins as the British Red Cross Society and later as the Ceylon Red Cross Society. Recognised by the International Committee of the Red Cross in 1952, it is now a member of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies. Committed to the principles of the Seville Agreement and the 2030 strategy, the organisation has a membership of 100,000 and 8,500 active volunteers and operates in every administrative district through 25 branches. Proactively engaged before, during and after disasters and health emergencies, the Sri Lanka Red Cross Society strives to enhance the lives of vulnerable populations without discrimination. For more information, visit www.redcross.lk

title: President takes wing to Australia
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe left the island yesterday (8) morning, to attend the Seventh Indian Ocean Conference (IOC) in Perth, Australia, from 9 – 10 February, on an invitation from the India Foundation and the Government of Australia. On his official visit, President Wickremesinghe will play a role in shaping discussions at the conference, slated as a vital forum for dialogue and cooperation within the Indian Ocean Region. Scheduled to deliver the keynote address, his presence underscores Sri Lanka’s commitment to regional collaboration, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said in a statement.  The event, themed ‘Towards a Stable and Sustainable Indian Ocean’, aims to foster cooperation among 40 participating nations. President Wickremesinghe’s participation reflects Sri Lanka’s proactive stance towards regional stability and development, according to the PMD. Accompanying the President was Foreign Minister Ali Sabry, who will address the plenary session titled ‘Our Blue Future: How can the Indian Ocean region work with island States to safeguard the health of our shared ocean resources’. Sabry’s participation highlights Sri Lanka’s focus on safeguarding shared ocean resources. Organised by the India Foundation, in collaboration with India’s Ministry of External Affairs and the Australian Government, along with support from the S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies, Singapore, and Perth-US Asia Centre, the conference seeks to chart a roadmap for the region’s future. “It is noteworthy that Sri Lanka previously hosted the second edition of the Indian Ocean Conference in 2017 under the leadership of then Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, now serving as the President. President Wickremesinghe’s attendance underscores Sri Lanka Government’s commitment to regional diplomacy and its active engagement in addressing common challenges for the collective benefit of Indian Ocean nations,” the PMD said.

title: Book Industry Makes Clarion Call for VAT Exemption
author: Author not found
Content: The latest salvo against the government’s imposition of value-added tax (VAT) on hitherto exempted sectors came on 2 February, from Sri Lanka’s book industry, which called for an immediate reversal of the decision to tax the sale of books at 18 per cent. Associations representing local publishers, printers, booksellers, importers, writers and academics came together to voice their opposition to the unavoidable hike in the prices of books consequent to the imposition of VAT, pointing to the pernicious long-term effects it would have on socio-economic development by making access to knowledge unaffordable to many. “We acknowledge that economic challenges spanning multiple government terms have led to a situation where the broader population has been required to shoulder the financial implications of the gradual national recovery,” the General Secretary of the Sri Lanka Book Publishers’ Association (SLBPA), Dinesh Kulatunga told the media at a news conference. “But, is it fair that this short-term requirement to boost government revenue should have the longer-term destructive consequence of retarding the education, culture, intellectual progress and personal development of generations of Sri Lankans, and negatively impact the development of the knowledge economy?” he queried. Speakers representing different stakeholder groups in the book industry also charged that with the indiscriminate extension of VAT to a highly sensitive and vulnerable sector like books, Sri Lanka was also in violation of the UNESCO Florence Agreement of 1950, to which the country was an early signatory and continues to be a Contracting State. The UNESCO Florence Agreement is a treaty that binds Contracting States to not impose customs duties and taxes on certain educational, scientific and cultural materials that are imported. “With the imposition of VAT on books, Sri Lanka attains the dubious distinction of becoming one of a very few countries that impose a tax on a vital source of knowledge and information,” the President of the Sri Lanka Book Publishers’ Association, Samantha Indeewara said. “What this means is that while the rest of the world is trying to make knowledge more accessible and inclusive at the grassroots level, Sri Lanka is trying to use this industry to raise government revenue, heedless of the serious ramifications.” “It is a textbook case of killing the goose that lays the golden eggs.” “According to the International Book Publishers Association, books are not a commodity like any other, but are strategic assets that activate the knowledge economy, facilitate upward social mobility as well as personal growth, and bring widespread medium and long term social, cultural and economic benefits.” It was also pointed out that the industry already contributes upwards of Rs 1 billion to the government’s tax revenue via the VAT paid by importers that supply 90 per cent of the raw materials used in the production of school textbooks and other books. The imposition of VAT on books therefore, results in an anomaly of double taxation for publishers, further aggravating a difficult situation. The government’s decision to impose 18 per cent VAT on books has already generated concern internationally, with the International Publishers Association (IPA) and the European and International Booksellers Federation (EIBF) writing to President Ranil Wickremesinghe to voice their objections. “Our member associations are united and have made efforts to engage with your office to explain the catastrophic consequences that such a tariff will have on the country’s book sector,” the two organisations said on 15 December 2023. “We stand in solidarity with Sri Lankan publishers and booksellers, and urge you to reconsider this measure for the benefit of the Sri Lankan literary landscape.” Among the Sri Lankan organisations and personalities that attended the news conference to call for the restoration of the VAT exemption on books were the Sri Lanka Book Publishers’ Association (SLBPA), the Sri Lanka Book Importers and Exporters Association, the Sri Lanka Writers Association and several leading writers, academics, educationists and author-publishers.

title: Chandima and Manori win Titles
author: Author not found
Content: Standard Chartered hosted its Priority Banking clients to the exclusive Standard Chartered Priority Golf Championship on 2 February at the Royal Colombo Golf Club.  The event featured an array of award titles, including the Standard Chartered Priority Golf Championship 2024 won by Chandima Desinghe and Runner-up – Vish Govindasamy. In the Ladies Division, the Winner was Manori Jayakody with Runner-up – Roshani Sangani. The newly introduced award, the Best Standard Chartered Staff Golfer was won by Murray Fernandesz.  The highly anticipated event brought together 72 golfers for a day of spirited competition and camaraderie, marking a successful return of the tournament, after a brief hiatus of one year.  The tournament has been a cornerstone of the Bank’s engagement with its Priority Banking clients, providing a platform for golf enthusiasts to showcase their skills and passion for the sport.  The exclusive event also demonstrates Standard Chartered’s commitment to providing value-added experiences for its Priority Banking clients, reflecting the Bank’s dedication to delivering an exceptional service and building lasting relationships.  Bingumal Thewarathanthri, Chief Executive Officer, Standard Chartered Sri Lanka, said, “Hearty congratulations to all our winners. The event marked an auspicious beginning for the New Year serving to create positive client engagement with our valued Priority Banking clients.” Standard Chartered Priority and the prestigious Royal Colombo Golf Club with its scenic golf course and rich heritage, have a long-standing affiliation. The tournament showcased the enduring partnership between the two entities and provided a perfect setting for Priority Banking clients to network. It also highlighted the Bank’s pledge to nurture a vibrant golfing community. Chamikara Wijesinghe, Head of Consumer, Private and Business Banking, Standard Chartered Sri Lanka, said, “We are deeply committed to sustaining our elite value propositions and curating the best experiences for clients. We are grateful that events such as the Golf Tournament enable us to meaningfully engage with our Priority Banking clients.”  Following the tournament, participants and guests were treated to a luncheon and an awards ceremony to conclude the day’s proceedings on a high note.

title: SL, China to resolve organic fertiliser issue amicably
author: Author not found
Content: In the year 2021, the organic fertilisers that the Ministry of Agriculture arranged to purchase from a private company in China subsequently reached a problematic situation, so various steps were taken from time to time to resolve the issue. However, due to some practical issues that arose during the implementation of that step, it took time to settle the deal. In particular, the Sri Lankan Government even had to pay a compensation of USD 6.9 million on the charge of damaging the reputation of the Chinese company that supplied the relevant organic fertilisers. Although it was decided to get other fertiliser and agricultural equipment to meet this amount, it was difficult to get another product suitable for agricultural needs because the same organic fertiliser is produced by the company concerned. The Cabinet of Ministers decided on 13 September 2022 to request the Minister of Foreign Affairs to come to a friendly agreement between China and Sri Lanka after discussing with all the relevant parties and submit the most appropriate proposals to the Cabinet to resolve this issue. On 7 February, a discussion was held at the Ministry of Agriculture under the patronage of Minister of Agriculture and Plantation Industries Mahinda Amaraweera to find a solution to the problematic situation caused by this organic fertiliser transaction. A group of officials including Janaka Dharmakeerthi, Secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture and Plantation Industries participated in that event. On the same day, the Ministry of Agriculture decided to take some more steps to resolve this issue. Thus, he decided to discuss this matter with the delegation including Ma Youxiang, Vice Minister of Agriculture and Rural Affairs of the People’s Republic of China, which will participate in the 37th Session of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) Regional Conference for Asia and the Pacific (APRC) to be held in Sri Lanka from 19-22 February. It was decided to discuss the resolution of the issues that arose during the implementation of the Court settlement between the Chinese Organic Fertiliser Company and the two State fertiliser companies in a manner that does not damage the friendly relations between the two countries as well as for the benefit of Sri Lankan farmers. The Minister of Agriculture instructed the Secretary of the Ministry to take steps to invite the relevant officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, including the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Ali Sabry, PC, to this discussion. Further, the Minister informed the officials that he and other officials are expected to discuss this issue with the Deputy Minister of Agriculture and Rural Affairs of the Chinese Government, who is due in the country shortly.

title: ‘Telemedicine’ programme for Horana DGH
author: Author not found
Content: The ‘Telemedicine’ programme will be established in the District General Hospital (DGH) Horana, where basic treatment services will be provided using modern technology on patients referred for emergency treatment. A senior spokesman for the Health Ministry, yesterday (8) said, the programme is aimed at providing the necessary primary care treatment, before referring patients, who are in serious condition, for emergency treatment to hospitals with more facilities, by utilising modern technology.  The Health Ministry would implement the new programme as a project in the primary care hospitals. The hot line 070 500 0450 was introduced in this connection. An awareness programme was conducted for district health service authorities of the District General Hospital Horana and health staff, including specialists, doctors and nurses.  The spokesman said, the Project named ‘Safe City’ was led by Specialist Dr. Isuru Gayan, at the District General Hospital Horana. It would enable Primary Health Care Hospitals to access any Consultant Specialist serving in a tertiary-care hospital, in any part of the island, using hi tech video technology in order to seek advice and even obtain a prognosis on the patient so that necessary treatment and care could be provided during the first hour (Golden Hour) when his or her life is in danger. Basic treatment services and necessary medicines could be provided to reduce the risk on the patient’s life as a result.  What needs to be noted is that the specialist doctor would be able to examine the patient through video technology – through visual media, whereas formerly it was done only through audio facilities.  The Ministry of Health is working to implement this new programme as a project in the primary hospital service, and an emergency number related to this service (070 500 0 450) has also been introduced. The district health service authorities of the Kalutara District, the hospital authority and the health staff including specialists, doctors and nurses were informed about the project named ‘Safe City’ and about the ‘Telemedicine’ project. It was led by Dr. Isuru Gayan, emergency treatment specialist at Horana District General Hospital. Ministry officials including the Deputy Director General (Medical Services I) of the Ministry of Health Dr. Lal Panapitiya, Director (Primary Care Services) Dr. Samantha Ranasinghe, Colombo District Health Services Director Specialist Dr. Chandana Gajanayake, Kalutara Divisional Health Services Director Dr. Sumal Nandasena, Horana District General Hospital Director Dr. Ayanthi Jayawardena and Deputy Director Dr. Hemantha Thushara were also present.

title: Small businesses, tourism stakeholders acclaim USAID-SLTDA Learning Expo in Pasikudah
author: Author not found
Content: Small business operators in the tourism industry acclaimed the Sustainable Niche Tourism Learning Expo conducted by the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) and Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA) at Amaya Hotel and Resort in Pasikudah recently. “It was a truly engaging event – the learning sessions were highly beneficial, equipping us with valuable skills and insights into the tourism industry,” said one participant. “The experiences of countries like Bhutan and Mongolia and their successful promotion of niche products to international travellers served as an inspiration for us, offering valuable lessons on how to effectively promote niche tourism within Sri Lanka,” he added. The event attracted over 100 small businesses and allied stakeholders, including the Eastern Province Tourism Council, the Chamber of Tourism and Industry, Trincomalee District Hotel Association, Batticaloa Hotelier District Association, Pasikudah Homestay District Association, Eastern Province Tour Guides Association, and the Batticaloa and Trincomalee Chambers of Commerce.  The expo was the fourth in a series of similar events conducted across the country and followed previous events held in Colombo, Galle, and Kandy. Participants learned about digital marketing, travel trends, and how to incorporate sustainability into their daily operations. They also had access to mentoring sessions with industry trailblazers and received toolkits focused on product development, marketing, promotions, and sustainability. Sri Lanka’s diverse tourism offerings hold immense potential for small businesses to cater to the demands of both international and domestic travellers. To establish a thriving tourism sector, it is vital to empower small business owners to innovate, refine their products, and deliver sustainable guest experiences aligned with traveller expectations.  Tourism is critical to Sri Lanka’s economy as it exits the pandemic and deals with its internal economic crisis.  Pre-pandemic tourism represented 12 per cent of the country’s GDP, generating USD 4.3 billion in revenue in 2018 and providing employment for three million people.  Sri Lanka is currently experiencing an encouraging resurgence in tourist arrivals and welcomed 1.5 million tourists in 2023 – double the figure of 720,000 recorded for the whole of 2022. Already popular as a tourism destination for its natural beauty and cultural heritage, in June 2023, Sri Lanka repositioned its tourism offering with the launch of 12 new niche tourism categories – from adventure tourism and cultural experiences to hosted/curated experiences and wellness and healing – offering differentiated experiences for travellers seeking an immersive holiday.  Niche tourism allows a destination to provide more inclusive opportunities for women, minority communities, and other disadvantaged groups by creating opportunities for them to participate in their own unique way.  USAID launched the tourism activity under the Indo Pacific Opportunity Project (IPOP) in July 2022 to support economic reforms and promote foreign direct investment in Sri Lanka.  The two-year project is assisting SLTDA to streamline and implement new policies and procedures to enable fast-tracking and attraction of foreign direct investment in the tourism sector. The learning expo is yet another positive step taken by IPOP to boost Sri Lanka’s tourism industry and its economic recovery.

title: SC grants AG leave to proceed
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (8), granted leave to proceed with the appeal filed by the Attorney General, seeking to set aside the interim order, by the Court of Appeal that invalidated the remand order on self-proclaimed prophet Jerome Fernando in connection with controversial remarks he made about various religions. title: CEB signs power purchase agreement with Rividhanavi
author: Author not found
Content: A power purchase agreement, for the 100 MW Ground Mount Solar power project in Siyambalanduwa, was signed by Rividhanavi (Pvt) Limited with the CEB yesterday (8). The project was advertised by the CEB for a competitive bidding process in September 2022, evaluated in 2023 and was awarded to the lowest and successful bidder at the end of 2023. Rividhanavi will also build the 27.5 km long Transmission line for the project and will transfer the line to the CEB. Rividhanavi (Pvt) Limited is a consortium of shareholders, comprising Lakdhanavi Limited, Windforce PLC and The Blue Circle PTE Ltd of Singapore. title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.
